title: What is phantom traffic and why is it ruining your life? - Benjamin Seibold

multiple-choice.question: What is a phantom traffic jam?

options.label: A
options.text: A traffic jam caused by an accident or road closure.

options.label: B
options.text: A traffic jam that forms for no apparent reason.

options.label: C
options.text: A traffic jam that occurs during rush hour.

options.label: D
options.text: A traffic jam that occurs on a highway with a low speed limit.

multiple-choice.question: What is the critical density of cars on the road that can lead to a phantom traffic jam?

options.label: A
options.text: Cars spaced less than 10 meters apart.

options.label: B
options.text: Cars spaced less than 35 meters apart.

options.label: C
options.text: Cars spaced less than 50 meters apart.

options.label: D
options.text: Cars spaced less than 20 meters apart.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why drivers tend to make traffic worse?

options.label: C
options.text: They don't have a good sense of the conditions ahead of them.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all driving in the same direction.

multiple-choice.question: How can self-driving cars equipped with data on traffic conditions ahead help prevent phantom traffic jams?

options.label: A
options.text: By accelerating rapidly out of a slowdown.

options.label: B
options.text: By braking harder to avoid a collision.

options.label: C
options.text: By maintaining a uniform speed that matches the average speed of the overall flow.

multiple-choice.question: In a recent experiment, how many self-driving cars were needed to dampen and prevent traffic waves?

options.label: A
options.text: One self-driving car for every 5 human drivers.

options.label: B
options.text: One self-driving car for every 10 human drivers.

options.label: C
options.text: One self-driving car for every 20 human drivers.

options.label: D
options.text: One self-driving car for every 30 human drivers.

title: How the Grinch Stole Christmas - Read aloud picture book

multiple-choice.question: What was the Grinch's reason for stealing Christmas from the Whos in Whoville?

options.label: A
options.text: He hated the noise of the Whos celebrating Christmas.

options.label: B
options.text: He hated the food that the Whos would eat during Christmas.

options.label: C
options.text: His heart was two sizes too small, and he wanted to stop Christmas from coming.

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to take the Whos' presents for himself.

multiple-choice.question: What did the Grinch do to Cindy Lou Who when she caught him stealing the Christmas tree?

options.label: A
options.text: He lied to her and told her that he was taking the tree to fix the light.

options.label: B
options.text: He hit her with his bag of presents.

options.label: C
options.text: He sent her to bed without any presents.

options.label: D
options.text: He gave her a present and sent her on her way.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the Grinch's heart after he realized that Christmas was still coming despite his efforts to stop it?

options.label: D
options.text: It turned into a different shape.

multiple-choice.question: What did the Grinch do after his heart grew three sizes?

options.label: A
options.text: He went back to his cave and took a nap.

options.label: B
options.text: He brought back the presents and food that he had stolen.

options.label: C
options.text: He built a new sleigh to take back to the Whos.

options.label: D
options.text: He went to Whoville to join in the Christmas celebration.

multiple-choice.question: What is the moral of the story "How the Grinch Stole Christmas"?

options.label: A
options.text: Christmas only comes from stores and packages.

options.label: B
options.text: Christmas is only for the rich and wealthy.

options.label: C
options.text: Christmas is a time for giving and sharing with others.

multiple-choice.question: C: His heart was two sizes too small, and he wanted to stop Christmas from coming.
A: He lied to her and told her that he was taking the tree to fix the light.
B: It grew three sizes.
B: He brought back the presents and food that he had stolen.
C: Christmas is a time for giving and sharing with others.

title: Why is cotton in everything? - Michael R. Stiff

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the cotton fibers developed by the Inca centuries ago?

options.label: A
options.text: They were made from iron or steel.

options.label: B
options.text: They were extremely long and thin.

options.label: C
options.text: They were made from cotton and could flex with blows.

options.label: D
options.text: They were very expensive to produce.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cell wall, and what happens to it during the growth of a cotton fiber?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the outer layer of the cell wall, and it stiffens first.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the inner layer of the cell wall, and it softens first.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the layer that causes the fiber to elongate quickly for about 16 days.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the layer that restricts further growth after about 16 days.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cellulose in the growth of a cotton fiber?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes up only 10% of the fiber's weight.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes up 34% of the cell wall at the first stage of growth.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes up over 90% of the fiber's weight after the secondary cell wall thickens.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in the growth of a cotton fiber.

multiple-choice.question: What determines the strength of a cotton fiber?

options.label: B
options.text: The density of the secondary cell wall.

options.label: C
options.text: The temperature at which the fiber grows.

options.label: D
options.text: The amount of water the fiber receives.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the living matter within a cotton fiber after it is fully grown?

options.label: A
options.text: It continues to grow and develop.

options.label: B
options.text: It dies off, leaving behind only the cellulose.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same, with no change.

options.label: D
options.text: It is replaced by new living matter.
